title: $MART: BUILDING A WEB3 ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS
body:
![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3NhiRYozwLflxYQMG7jTG.jpg?height=3543&width=7086)

**$MART (MART) is the governance token of Metavers Artspace, a web3 fine arts e-learning service focused on exploring metamodernism and artificial intelligence. The platform integrates art research into the blockchain economy and enhances education's reward system through a learn-and-earn mechanism. $MART governance tokens give holders the right to vote on issues that govern the development and operations of the blockchain project Metavers Artspace.**

Art Education has always been gated by central authorities to accept only a small number of students for art schools, while measuring success depends on a board of directors, grades and credit points. At the same time, artistic education and creative thinking are underrepresented in the age of AI and automation. Opportunities to do business and sell artworks while studying are limited at traditional art schools.

Metavers Artspace's mission is to expand opportunities for art students with a decentralized system. The cyber-hybrid platform makes learning more fun with game-fi and social-fi elements. Art students can browse lessons, respond and get rewards. The absence of a central authority and a P2P art evaluation system makes voting a key aspect. Metavers Artspace is launching a mirror crowdfund contract to develop the DeSci platform and build an academy of fine arts on chain, starting with the tokenization of exhibition space for the academicians.

![Make your learnings count with $MART](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Tuggud0GYsmFe7xUXIgtS.jpg?height=1771&width=3543)

## How does it work?

1. Get a crypto wallet
2. Back this project
3. Enter an amount you want to exchange
4. Get $MART (1 ETH = 1000 $MART)

* Backers deposit ETH to fund Metaverse Artspace in exchange for $MART tokens.
* Backers of the project automatically receive $MART tokens in exchange for their ETH. The token tracks how much each backer has contributed to Metavers Artspace. Tokens are issued at a ratio of 1000 tokens to 1 ETH.
* The token represents a proof of patronage and an economic stake in the potential success of the platform by routing future revenue back to the token.
* Backers can use their tokens to enter the community space and start the application process. $MART tokens represent the membership in the Metavers Artspace community and unlocks the token-gated server. In the educational model $MART governance tokens represent a more equitable, decentralized, and transparent governance method.
* If the funding target is hit, Metavers Artspace will start to develop the DeSci platform with the application stages: 1. Transcript, 2. Application, 3. Portfolio, 4. Rewards.
* If the stretch goal is hit, Metavers Artspace will start to implement more $MART burning mechanisms, use cases and earning functions.
* $MART tokens can be traded like any ERC-20 token, or redeemed for underlying ETH.

[crowdfund://0x4e62FDc9DED7B6b4F58DAD5877aCB37E78FEe2D2?features=overview,editions,podium,backers](crowdfund://0x4e62FDc9DED7B6b4F58DAD5877aCB37E78FEe2D2?features=overview,editions,podium,backers)

### Rewards for Backers

Patron Podium NFTs will unlock advantages and exclusive opportunities at the graduate shows of the Metavers Artspace academicians. NFT Tiers will unlock a special edition of the basic literature “Proof of Singularity”.

**Proof of Singularity** is the is the first interactive eBook publication in web3. It is the living community mission of Metavers Artspace that gets reviewed every season and re-written once every few semesters with the community as co-author. As educational material for the application process, the NFT gives access to courses on the community server with an AI-Teacher. The book publication on metamodernism, artificial intelligence and the concept of singularity addresses new technologies from an artistic perspective and analyzes the social impact.

The NFT edition integrates web3 advantages into the publishing of eBooks: resell your eBook / get limited, collectable and rare editions of your favorite book / the book is your key to DeFi / using your book as collateral / collect your book as NFT and showcase the books you collect.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_lg5gtsWBiXWjRGCCS0WD.PNG?height=1997&width=1664)

## Overview

**$MART is the governance token of Metavers Artspace, a Web3 art education DeSci App with inbuilt Game-Fi and Social-Fi elements. $MART is used for art evaluation.**

$MART is built around a sustainable social activity - studying and gaining knowledge. It is the first project for a blended-learning solution in the field of art education to effectively bring to life a functioning learn-and-earn concept. With the advancement of AI and automation, creative and abstract thinking becomes increasingly important.

Users equip themselves with NFTs in the form of learning material and get rewarded for educational activity. By responding to the materials, creative writing, project presentations, visiting a cultural place or exhibiting, users will earn game currency, which can either be used in-game, or cashed out for profit.

With game-Fi and hybrid learning, $MART aims to nudge millions toward a more fun and effective e-learning solution, combat the limitations of online learning and connect the public to Web 3.0. It supports academic researcher, artists, experts from the industry and students while simultaneously hinging on it’s Social-Fi aspect to build a long-lasting educational platform fostering user generated Web 3.0 content.

## Governance and Art Evaluation

$MART is used for voting as a P2P art evaluation system:

$MART is the Metavers Artspace governance token to vote on proposals and portfolio projects, access the community server and join community events. With the governance token, art investors are also listed on the allowlist for minting artworks at graduate shows.

### Voting System

The absence of a central authority makes voting on proposals as art evaluation a central aspect in metavers artspace.

The voting system also enables users to vote on modifications in articles from „Proof of Singularity“, the living community mission that gets reviewed every season and re-written once every few semesters.

Each proposal can be scheduled to be voted on by the token holders in a space. Users can describe the proposal, add options to vote on, and select the voting strategy.‍

The decentralized voting system allows users to create proposals and vote off-chain. It allows users to choose from multiple voting systems and use $MART to calculate voting power and to vote without gas. The POAP Plugin allows voters to claim a POAP badge as a proof-of-vote.

The voting system gives users the tools to customize governance for their community. It allows users to carry out governance in an organized way. It makes governance more accessible and affordable since the data is stored off-chain.

Voting Type: Each voting type calculates the weight of an individual wallet differently:‍

* Single Choice Voting: Each voter can choose a maximum of one option to support with their entire voting power.
* Approval Voting: Each voter can select multiple options and their voting power will be distributed equally among the selected options.
* Quadratic Voting: Voters spread their voting power across options. The number of voters is weighted higher than the number of votes than an option receives. This method of voting removes power away from the whales in your ecosystem.
* Ranked Choice Voting: Voters rank options from most preferred to least preferred. Votes are counted for each voter’s top choice. If an option has more than 50% of the votes based on first-choice, that option wins. If not, the option with the least votes is eliminated and this process is repeated until a clear winner emerges or there is only one option left.
* Weighted Voting: Similar to Approval voting where voters can select multiple choices, but voters are allowed to choose how much of their voting power to allocate to each vote.

Start Date and End Date: Allows users to specify when a proposal goes live and stops accepting votes. It is important to specify a window that is not too short to allow the community members to have ample time to vote.

Block Number: Gives users the ability to decide who can or can’t vote, minimizing the chance that proposals will be influenced by a recent purchase of tokens by a Whale or by spreading tokens across multiple wallets.

An ENS name is required to use the voting system.

### Professional Feedback System

Additional, small groups of specialists - “committees” or “pods” - making decisions over the evaluation of art.

## Tokenomics

### Token Distribution

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/eBSjLd8POiNixjYwuVUOa.jpg?height=3543&width=3543)

### Token Earning Starting Date

Stage 4: Earning: Learn-and-Earn kick off

### Token Utility

Unlock Community Spaces and Server

Entry for Events

Pre-Sale/Allow List for graduate shows

### Token Platform Use Case

In-App Marketplace:

\->Mint Portfolio and Materials

\->Learn-and-Earn

\->In-App Wallet Swap

### Token Burning Mechanics

* Mint Portfolio
* Upgrade Material
* Level-Up Portfolio
* Unlocking Certificates
* Votings
* Swap to USDC

### Token Earning Mechanics

$MART is earned when a user responds to learning materials.

Each day, a set number of $MART will be unlocked to earn.

The daily release of $MART follows exponential decay pattern.

### Finance & Ecosystem

How the project profits

Metavers Artspace takes small taxes from in-app activities, such as trading or NFT minting. All assets on the marketplace are owned by individual users and the majority of earnings in the app are made by users. A Royalty Fee is payable to the NFT learning material creators.

### Materials

The quantity of the NFT learning materials represents the number of students who are admitted to a course. When students finish the course, they can sell the NFT to give the spot to another student. Each time the NFT is sold, the creator of the learning material gets a creator fee.

The quality of the NFT learning materials is approved by institutions, experts or researchers. Each learning material creator must have a professional background e.g. in academic research, art market, creative industry or blockchain economy.

The focus of the NFT learning materials is on exploring the concepts of AI and Metamodernism with contemporary art and creative writing in different ecosystems.

## How to apply

1\. Transcript

Activate your prior knowledge with the basic learning material “PROOF OF SINGULARITY” ($INGULARITY). The first eBook publication in web3 unlocks eLearning courses with AI-Teachers.

2\. Application

Choose a program and use $MART for the submission, governance and voting rights.

3\. Portfolio

Submit your portfolio that demonstrates your personal ideas and interests along with technical abilities.

4\. Rewards

Claim a subdomain on the metaversartspace.eth domain and get your first reward. Enter the platform with an in-app marketplace, DEX and Wallet. Respond to the tokenized learning materials to get earnings and certificates.

## Vision

Long-term goals are real estate, the growing publication of materials and the development of an actual Bachelor/ Master/ PHD system.

## About

**Metavers Artspace was founded by the art researcher and curator Carina Lue with a notion of art as contemporary knowledge production that will last in our ever-changing world. As an education leader, she is an expert in hybrid aesthetic forms with a focus on new media and technological innovations. Technology can not only generate sales arguments for consumers, it can also simplify access to education, enable new forms of education and strengthen collective awareness of abstract and international problem solutions.**

title: Fluence - The Web3 Substitute To AWS?
body:
**Fluence is a peer-to-peer platform, ready to revolutionize the way blockchain evolves. In this article, let’s find out what is Fluence, and its potential & growth aspects.**

### TLDR

*   What is Fluence?
*   Features of Fluence Network
*   Aqua and Consensus
*   Peer-To-Peer Digital Economy
*   Use Cases

Fluence is a community-driven, open-source, permissionless, and decentralized blockchain ecosystem. Fluence aims to help developers to host peer-to-peer applications in a trustless manner.

You might be wondering, several web2 platforms provide for application development, then why Fluence? Let me explain it in simple terms.

Developers want their apps to be as secure and smooth as possible. At the same time, users also want their data to be as safe and private as possible. But the existing web2 infrastructures are vulnerable to hacks. We all have heard how hackers stole user [data from McDonalds](https://www.wsj.com/articles/mcdonalds-hit-by-data-breach-in-south-korea-taiwan-11623412800) in Korea and Taiwan. Fluence could be the go-to web3 solution for data privacy and safety. But how?

Fluence hosts apps that run independently of centralized institutions and cloud providers. Google Cloud and Amazon Web Services influence how the data is transferred and accessed around the globe. There is nothing wrong with that, yet having a robust web3 alternative can’t hurt, right!

However, in a peer-to-peer world, data security is often overlooked. But not for long. Fluence offers an integrated solution that can ensure app data never ends up in the wrong hands.

Is that all? No! Fluence has a ton of unique features in its sleeves. Fluence innovates the next generation of internet computing that is permissionless, scalable, and composable. Let’s take one bite at a time to understand these concepts.

Permissionless means a user does not require permission to interact with the network. It’s like an open supermarket, without any cashiers! But on the blockchain, no single user can misbehave and try and do fraudulent transactions. Permissionless also implies anyone can deploy applications using the extensive database of Fluence.

But what if you are a high-end developer of apps with millions of users? Or whether you are a small-scale developer with a few thousand users? Don’t worry, Fluence has got you covered. Fluence offers high scalability so that each application can host billions of users. The most interesting fact here is the ability of these applications to create subnets on the Fluence network. These subnets act as arms of Fluence without affecting speed and reliability. In technical terms, it is known as sharding.

![Features](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*jnz7HyDfEYto83ALAlJsOQ.png)

Features

### Prominent Features of Fluence

Okay, now your apps are working smoothly, but being a vigilant developer, you are concerned about whether there is a verification mechanism.

Most other blockchain projects would explain how the technology is secure etc. But Fluence aims to be inclusive of both web3 and web2 people. That’s why Fluence provides you with the choice of selecting a specific validator whom you can trust. Let me put this straight. If someone wants to verify their own application data, they can become a validator on Fluence. Yes, you, as a developer, get to enjoy complete autonomy.

Above all, Fluence provides a flexible consensus mechanism. Explaining the consensus mechanism is beyond the scope of this article. But Fluence assures the trustless consensus is as good as you think. It enables applications to opt for consensus for specific tasks. In a nutshell, Fluence supports various consensus mechanisms as Aqua libraries.

### What is Aqua?

Aqua is an open-source programming language fuelling fluence. Yes, it’s the heart and soul of Fluence that helps to implement better coordination in consensus. Aqua is worthwhile in implementing trusted consensus algorithms like Raft and trustless ones like Tendermint. That’s not it. Aqua allows for creating and sustaining peer-to-peer environments. It is much required, as peer-to-peer(p2p) transactions must be kept separate from p2p computations. Also, it forms the basis of an open, decentralized application marketplace. Aqua is also Turing-complete, based on process calculus, and allows to implementation of custom algorithms for any network topology.

### Relevance of Fluence Network in the Modern Era

The Internet envisions to bring equality to all. Yet, a generic digital divide exists, and multinational conglomerates own users’ data. These companies sell user data to others, making more profit. Take the example of google and amazon. They dominate the current data infrastructure niche. Eventually, it leads to data totalitarianism. The concentration of private data in a non-private environment is a threat to data management in general. How? Imagine a day when Google or Amazon fails. In a world that considers data the new gold, a system with a single point of failure is a significant risk.

The present world is fast becoming digital-oriented. More people use the internet daily, creating a large amount of data. This phenomenon is like to increase in the future. At a point, the existing system will fail terribly, leaving user data vulnerable. This tipping point is not exactly far away. Hence decentralization is the best practical solution and way forward. This is the opportunity for the peer-to-peer market model to dethrone business-business or business-client models. Logically speaking, Fluence has a better chance to lead this wave of decentralization. It provides flexibility, accessibility, and usability in addition to security to applications.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*OM0lyG0NWfEt8j-3MJInJw.png)

Adobe’s Digital Economy Index underlines this. In the last seven years, the digital purchasing power of the United States has increased by 23%. More people are choosing to live online. It further accelerates the need for decentralized data management efforts. P2P allows applications to connect with users and keep sensitive, private data under their control. Essentially, users own their data in a true sense. Fluence can facilitate this upcoming P2P revolution with the right tools.

### Some Use Cases

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*WYCPDFFSZKIlT9fZ7pFu-Q.png)

As Fluence is a cloud computer, it has good deal of applications, from messaging to the internet of things. It can host web apps and other communication platforms.

Fluence can build censorship-resistant applications that can run on users’ devices. These apps can be social networks or streaming protocols. In an ever-growing creator economy, Fluence can become the beacon of hope for those from countries with high censorship norms. Fluence also removes the necessity of a central authority to manage the applications. It helps DAOs to establish and run sustainably. If DAOs are healthy, communities will become the finest force displaying the essence of decentralization.

### Comparison of Aqua and Traditional Languages

First and foremost, programs written on Aqua are not executed fully at deployed devices. Firstly, the code is processed into particles. Then, particles travel over the network to trigger functions on remote peers. Sounds complicated? Not really. Consider particles as a bag of candies and each peer as a kid. Now you take the candy bag and go to each kid. The kid will demand a specific candy, and you can comfortably deliver the candy from the candy bag. Each peer has a different set of requests and requirements. The program chooses the function and activates the request. Simple, right?

Let’s also go through the WebAssembly runtime in Fluence, called Marine. Marine executes computations triggered by Aqua programs. Marine also provides a secure code sandbox. It ensures that hosted code can only access the system with explicit permission. These services are very lightweight and fast, and effectively, it performs as a distributed serverless engine. Marine and Aqua together standardize open source components for data processing.

Well, it's a wrap. To know more about Fluence, visit its website <https://fluence.network/>.

title: MacOS + IOS x Crypto + OpSec = ?
body:
In my favorite chat room recently I [was asked](https://t.me/lobsters_chat/363628), in light of recent events, would it be safer to use MacOS & IOS for work? Is it true that they have better security? I don't have a definite answer here - both yes and no. Let's get to the bottom of it!

First of all, There are a lot of malware for MacOS/IOS, the thing is that exploits 0days/1day for MacOS/IOS costs slightly more in than Windows/Android.

There is no difference, just a difference in the price of preparation and in the price of different exploits (including file gluing exploits or delivery exploits - they always cost more), I suggest you go to [Zerodium](https://zerodium.com/) and see the prices.

In general, the toolkit is more or less the same so don't assume that MacOS is more secure. Again, it is based on FreeBSD. In other words, know who is working against you and what they are capable of.

In other words, the chances of getting into a massive attack are less, but the chances of being hacked by someone who is not sorry to spend 5-10 thousand dollars to prepare for your hack are equal on all devices and almost all operating systems.

Hackers also care about economics, profit and cost. If they are confident they can take the risk. Keep that in mind.

Use Qubes OS, Whonix, Tails or Graphene OS (which is way better then closed and thus unable to estimate risks IOS. Jailbreaking a device makes everything even worse) but some of them require a lot of preparation work and do not have out of the box security! **But.** Any secure OS can't help you, if you don't care about simple security rules - keep that in mind. title: Are Miners Selling Their $BTC?
body:
**Bitcoin and major altcoins are in a relief rally. Even though some are down 80% from their all-time highs, the rally is a breather for bulls. Bitcoin pumped to 21k and then to 22k, with low volumes. But what about whales? Are they selling this rally? Can the pump last for long, given the worsening macroeconomic conditions? Let's find out!**

**TLDR**

*   Miners Capitulating
*   Consequences of A Capitulation Event
*   Interesting Onchain Activity in Ethereum
*   Binance Whales and Their Masterplan

## Miners Capitulating

It is no big secret that miners control most of the active bitcoin liquidity. Yes, whales are influential players, but many miners, over time, become whales. And when the miners sell their bitcoin reserves, it points to an eventual bottom of the market. Of course, when miners sell, it leads to short-term dips too. But for long-term enthusiasts of bitcoin, capitulation is a solid buy signal.

**So, what exactly is Miners' reserve?** It is the amount of Bitcoin held by miners. At the same time, it is worth noting that the value accounts for affiliate miners only. That means the reserve excludes old miners who don't have any mining activity now.

### What Is The Status Of Capitulation?

Since 2021, miners have been consistently accumulating bitcoin. It also means that the miners have not realized any significant profit in the last 18 months!

![Capitulation](https://mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FyOppEJpWc3CRZ2Em3ytI-.png\&w=3840\&q=90)

Capitulation

But now, miners are forced to sell their biggest bag since 2021.\
<!-- -->Some major reasons are;

1.  Increasing mining costs
2.  Decreased price of bitcoin

Many miners are left with no option other than to sell some of their reserves.

### What Are The Consequences?

As discussed earlier, the most critical consequence is a short-term price fall. There is too much selling pressure from miners and minimal buying pressure from investors. There is a supply-demand mismatch, and the market might settle for a lower bitcoin price.

## Interesting Onchain Activity In Ethereum

Ethereum had a great turn of events, especially after [announcing the merge date](https://twitter.com/WeekInEthNews/status/1548101125101867009). It was crucial for the entire altcoin market (most pumped 10-30%). But Ethereum is still trading below its 2018 all-time high.

Two Transactions caught my attention today.

    Today, on 18th July, 20.4K ETH was transferred to the FTX exchange. 

The wallet holds almost $250K worth of assets now, and its primary and secondary wallets hold $48 million and $31 million in assets respectively. Most importantly, the wallets are stable coin dominated and are 2-3 years old.

![source : Etherscan](https://mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FV6DAyB0uMvJcpCyCqT4hp.png\&w=1920\&q=90)

source : Etherscan

This tells us that, at least some of the whales do not believe the bear market is over.

![source : Etherscan](https://mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FEt21v-JRCKfZj6NalxkXZ.png\&w=1920\&q=90)

source : Etherscan

Like the first wallet, this one is also a whale wallet that holds 84.5K ETH and $587 million worth of assets.

This whale is also panicking, trying to sell all his altcoins.

![](https://mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FUpGG38Ma4SsDAxqVFd7bw.png\&w=3840\&q=90)

The above two examples tell us three things particularly;

1.  Whales are not happy with the market. They will possibly dump on relief rallies.
2.  It is better to take profits when the market is green.
3.  We might experience a long bear market this time.

## Masterplan Of Binance Whales

Binance is the biggest centralized crypto exchange with the most volume and liquidity. These factors make Binance a whale destination. But has the inflows to Binance affected bitcoin?

Let’s see how bitcoin price action is correlated with the exchange inflow into Binance.

![](https://mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2Fcl4MS45nRTUHRCELJcPJ1.png\&w=3840\&q=90)

In mid-march 2022, the exchange inflow to Binance was at moderate levels.\
<!-- -->Bitcoin was ranging between 38k and 47k at that time.

But as soon as the price crashed to 32k in the first week of May, whales started sending their bitcoin holdings to exchanges to sell in profit.

But the bitcoin price was relatively stable for the next two weeks. Probably whales were looking for exit liquidity, and did not want the price to dip further.

Whales succeeded and were able to sell their BTC at 32k- 30k level, which precipitated another fall to 20k in June 2022.

Since then, BTC has been trading in the 19k - 21k price range. However, on 17th July, inflows broke the moderate levels again!

Are Binance whales planning another dump? Only time will tell. However, analyzing past behaviors, they are likely to grab exit liquidity from the shorts liquidation, etc.

title: An Update on Crypto Markets and Personal Direction
body:
# An Update on Crypto Markets and Personal Direction

I’ve never been one to write in a blog-related style nor share much regarding personal situations. I don’t believe my experiential position is adequate for telling truly insightful stories. Nevertheless, some thoughts are due for the markets and what I want to be writing about in the near future.

# Macro

> The Macro looks bad but won’t be as bad as it seems.

I’ve never been a macro person — opting into the very grounded and very self-righteous belief that macroeconomists are always right in the direction but never on the timing. Frankly, I don’t believe anyone ever gets it right on timing hence firms that make themselves out to be armchair anthropological gods do little to actually profit vs everyone else but certainly get the most invitations to be on television and present in economic conferences. Since the dawn of COVID unfortunately the markets have largely been beholden to macro events with everyone's eyes glued to FOMC meeting notes trying to understand how they can one-up the US central bank as it decides whether to shoot themselves in the heart or the lungs.

Bottom line is that the free money era is currently in steep decline, interest rates will continue to climb and growth + sectors that relied on printing will continue to decline at the pace of rapid spikes down followed by temporary relief spread throughout. The question is no longer when the fed will turn hawkish but whether that hawk is a wild beast or from a zoo (my bet is on the zoo). Neither outcome is good. I don’t foresee the next 8 months being a good environment to DCA into your favourite tech companies that are -80%. However, if you are a legitimate practitioner from the house of DCA — please continue to buy into real companies with real cashflows: Google, Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft. My personal bet on Palantir is listed because this is my article, but also the pending geopolitical state of the world supports Palantir in making a boatload of money.

As I am not a macro expert, there are currently a few narratives being watched by people far smarter than I: [The corporate debt crisis](https://medium.com/galois-capital/btc-and-the-pending-corporate-credit-collapse-3c59814e625b), [the potential collapse of the European Central Bank and EU](https://blog.bitmex.com/the-doom-loop/), and apparently [auto loans are having their own “08 moment”](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-13/bonds-backed-by-car-loans-are-selling-at-fastest-pace-in-years).

My belief in markets overall remains positive, yes the next year or maybe two will continue to be bad and we can let the macro traders continue partying on but eventually, we will make it to the next bull cycle where everything will be good again. Stack cash right now and be ready to hunt once Spring comes back.

TL;DR: Times are bad but get a job and try to make as much cash as possible. Get the cash ready to buy severely depreciated assets, you can DCA or wait a few months to see if the market is ready to stop imploding from government incompetence.

# Defi Opportunities

Back to the actual world of crypto. I actually see a great opportunity to buy heavily depreciated Defi governance tokens in projects that have proven utility or mechanisms that can support scale without ponzinomics like Terra. Here is my list and the prices at the time of writing (ToW), they also have quite good tokenomics given that FDV isn't a multiple higher than 2:

1. Convex Finance ($50 peak → $7.80 ToW)
2. Compound ($854 peak → $55.83 ToW)
3. Aave ($632 → $90.06 ToW)
4. Maker ($6012 → 986.82 ToW)

The reasoning is quite simple: TradFi wants into crypto, hell crypto-natives are racing to create funds and aching to deploy capital at new generational lows. The first gateway to enter will be Defi projects, particularly the governance tokens. The listed projects all have great Mcap:FDV ratios, working projects with functional utility, and also funds like power, so getting to vote on proposals is their view of “bettering the ecosystem” through their involvement.

I haven’t looked deeply into each whitepaper to figure out whether the value capture happens exactly at the protocol or token level, frankly, I’m a bit lazy to validate this hunch too much but I want to put this into writing as an obvious trade and will gather more evidence down the line. See you in 2024.

# NFTs

Surprisingly NFTs haven’t completely died yet. I had an interesting thesis I wanted to witness: In the instance that the underlying asset such as ETH or SOL depreciates heavily, would the NFT price rebase into dollars or remain priced in crypto? To put it into English, would a monkey Jpeg worth 100 ETH = $400,000 given that ETH is $4000 still be priced at the $400,000 tag if ETH declines to $1000 or remain at 100 ETH? As we can see from the graph below on BAYC floor prices from the last 90 days

Prices did fall from a high of 149E to their current floor at 88E, but it's holding consistent

Price of ETH during the same time period,

This is actually quite fascinating as it disproves that NFTs were by nature purely speculative vehicles and community forces indeed lend a perception of value. Apes together = strong.

Yes, the dollar value fell in conjunction with the fall in price on ETH but the fact that NFTs didn’t go to 0 immediately proves that they aren’t simply a leverage slider on crypto but actually might hold on their own as an asset class that currently traces its underlying asset. Does the same apply to non-blue chips or new kids on the block such as Azuki?

Azuki also had a near 50% drop, also holding the line

I won’t look at every collection on OpensSea but here is Moonbirds as well

30E peak to currently 22E

The conclusion was that we saw declines but the declines in NFTs weren’t amplitudes above their underlying asset. Certain collections even have spikes in price based purely on community speculation and independent trading patterns that disregard the performance of crypto. The only firm conclusion I can say at this stage is that NFTs are certainly going nowhere and will definitely come back stronger next cycle. As to whether they will stand as a flight for capital preservation during an apocalyptic event or worse; an extended bear market is too soon to tell.

# Hubris vs Conviction

We had a few instances of complete Hubris that I found incredibly valuable as learning opportunities.

The implosion of 3AC which used non-collateralized loans to margin long crypto to their demise and the creditors that were brave enough to lend hundreds of millions to billions of customer funds is an insane yet exemplary example of the confidence game.

This was not the only example nor the first of its kind, it led me to wonder the following question:

> Where is the line between hubris and conviction?

If we look at some of the greatest trading opportunities within the past 5 years, the best examples were:

1. Holding Bitcoin from $9 to $69,000
2. Holding Tesla stock from $6 to $1200
3. Holding Dogecoin from $0.011 to $0.77

These were simply three prominent examples that came to mind, and where one could reason there were several reasons these prices exploded as they did, a part of me wonders whether the difference between conviction and Hubris is whether or not the idea simply worked out or not.

Hardcore early adopters or believers will say that they always saw this coming. We’ve heard the tales of basement tech-bros mining Bitcoin dreaming of a new financial system in 2011, families that sold all their assets to buy Tesla stock and Dogecoin millionaires that might’ve gotten lucky because they liked the dog meme. I find it ridiculous to juxtapose these principles in stating that 3AC were conmen or that Do Kwon was a scammer, to me they were also believers and heroes of their own stories that were fighting important battles.

There may exist a world where Tesla did not have every advantage in the book to help them succeed nor the retail marketing efforts that drove hysteria to prop their stock at 100x earnings valuation. There may exist a world where Bitcoin was shut down by central authorities long before its cult could prosper. There may exist a universe where Doge was never more than a meme. In contrast, there could also be a situation where Terra did indeed reach critical mass to survive without its egregious emissions structure or 3AC’s supercycle did come to fruition. The people at the helm of these ideas or the ones who all-inned their savings at the very beginning often stood by their thesis as “conviction”. I believe that the line between that and Hubris is often just the resultant conclusion that is grandfathered by the onlookers.

My conclusion for this thought-nugget is this, a conviction in an idea is good, but more often than not we must realize that even though we can find a thousand reasons why an idea should succeed, in the event of its failure there will be a thousand reasons dug up for why it failed. We cannot afford to be blind-sighted in good ideas once the market has turned against us, we cannot be arrogant in ever thinking our conviction *isn’t* hubris. The best way to trade may indeed be Sorisian, recognize and pull out of failures fast but double down heavily on winners, and do not marry ideas. At the end of the day, the market decides who is correct and who is wrong by the dollars in your account and the debt in your legal proceedings.

title: Thoughts on Community Support
body:
Hey again. Maybe it’s “Hey” for the first time. I don’t know. Hey.

### tl;dr

I think this full piece is worth reading but here’s the CliffsNotes version:

* [Mint this NFT](https://create.zora.co/editions/0x516eebd8b290d41e24c2cc85b88ef97629869e30) by [Shawntel](https://twitter.com/shawntelco) by Saturday, July 30.
* Claim a free new song of mine as an NFT on Saturday.
  Link on Saturday.
* We’re exploring new models of supporting each other as artists in web3.

### The Problem

I’ve been thinking a lot lately about how artists can support each other more in this world of web3 and NFTs outside of a retweet, outside of coming to a drop party, outside of pumping each other up on social media. I’ve been thinking a lot about how as creators of NFTs we talk about the concept of building community but that conversation is primarily focused on a community of potential buyers and supporters. I often wonder what we can do for each other that might be able to create a more direct impact than what we’re doing on social media.

There are too many people in this realm who feel like they have answers to questions that don’t have specific answers. I’m often one those people. This specific article is me being one of those people.

### A Solution (?)

One potential solution I’ve come up with is creating networks of support around our NFT sales. I think we have been doing a great job with token gating, for instance. Early sales for our previous collectors, allow lists for our early non-financial supporters, raffles and the like. Taking this model but applying it to be artists you want to support as opposed to collectors of your work has an opportunity to create a network effect, not only for you, but for the artists you support.

### Putting It Into Action

One of my all-time favorite folks in web3, [Shawntel](https://twitter.com/shawntelco), has been dropping a handful of art lately on Zora, and has recently been hit with a need to generate funds. As someone who doesn’t have much money (you guys should probably buy my NFTs) but has a lot of ideas, I’ve decided to create a song that will be **FREE TO MINT** if you [acquire an edition of the Lotus Flower Bomb NFT of Shawntel’s on Zora](https://create.zora.co/editions/0x516eebd8b290d41e24c2cc85b88ef97629869e30). She made 20 editions of this, so there will be up to 20 editions up for grabs. I’ll take a snapshot at midnight on Saturday, July 30th (that’s when Saturday starts, eastern time), and the NFTs will be available for the wallets who have collected the NFT by then.

![Lotus Flower Bomb by Shanwtel](https://ipfs.io/ipfs/bafybeid7layedx65cy2g2nnyhh3bqnqabdtpdislaugf4zzr5tm2igo25a)

### Why should we support Shawntel?

This is a great question for you to ask yourself. Aside from the work itself being fire, there are few in the NFT space who advocate for other artists like Shawntel does. [She created a huge directory of NFTs by Black folks via twitter that’s easy to browse and easy to share](https://twitter.com/shawntelco/status/1407898933699940352?s=21&t=rb_pRcYyX1wBzhJHelMZNQ). Aside from the work itself being fire, she’s created a community for Black folks in the space aptly named “WE BLACK AF ON THE BLOCKCHAIN” which has been a hub for Black creatives worldwide to share work, talk through things, collaborate and grow together. Aside from the work itself being fire, Shawntel shows up for you and advocates for you when you aren’t around and is an all around gem of a person. She’s definitely a model of what someone who creates community and supports others looks like, and we should support her in kind.

### I like this idea, why isn’t everyone doing it?

Honestly, the whole process is clunky as fuck. New tools constantly emerge and while one of the greatest features of this tech is to be able to build on top of it just through using tokens, it takes a little bit for things to catch up. Even on Mirror (where you’re reading this), I can’t embed the NFT directly because it’s built on a new Zora feature set. [You’re gonna buy the NFT on Zora](https://create.zora.co/editions/0x516eebd8b290d41e24c2cc85b88ef97629869e30). I’m gonna mint my song on my own ERC-721 smart  contract using the (also new) [claim page feature in Manifold Studios](https://twitter.com/manifoldxyz/status/1542566462434316288?s=21&t=rb_pRcYyX1wBzhJHelMZNQ). I have to wait until Saturday to mint the song, because there isn’t a proper token gate created for this yet and I have to import the addresses from the snapshot at the time of minting.

It is all very clunky, but to support others it’s worth it.

### Cool.

Yes, very. I’ll talk to you guys later.

title: NFT Events During Hottest Week In London
body:
**Benyamin Ahmed**

**We might have just had the hottest week in UK history but that did not keep the London NFT crowd indoors.**

After attending Lisbon and [NYC](https://mirror.xyz/workinfintech.eth/EE3crMUemQyoC15Px_a_tcEVcUP6RoDC_omwGia3Wcc) I was keen to participate in an event in my home town, London.

I was fortunate to speak at not one but three London based events in the same week. On Tuesday 19th July, exactly one year after the launch of [Weird Whales](https://weirdwhalesnft.com/), I spoke to a full-house at [web3 London](https://twitter.com/web3_london) in the stunning Microsoft Reactor building.

[https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1549404045823049728](https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1549404045823049728)

[https://twitter.com/web3_london/status/1549088602331783169](https://twitter.com/web3_london/status/1549088602331783169)

Organised by [Gerard Sans](https://twitter.com/gerardsans), I spoke about my journey into NFTs and listened to talks by [Lauren Ingram](https://mobile.twitter.com/LaurenWeb3), [Pauline](https://mobile.twitter.com/pauline_unik) from [Unik Labs](https://www.uniklabs.xyz/) and [Irina Liakh](https://mobile.twitter.com/IrinaLiakh).

[https://twitter.com/IrinaLiakh/status/1549521558934360069](https://twitter.com/IrinaLiakh/status/1549521558934360069)

[Pauline](https://twitter.com/pauline_unik) delivered an interesting talk on fashion in the metaverse: $1bn+ spent on skins in Fortnite, 1 in 5 Roblox users update their avatars daily with 3B gamers now globally. Huge market with huge margins!

On Thursday I was invited to speak at the [stunning](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5bU06dLGkOs) Magna Carta House by [Chana Kanzen](https://mobile.twitter.com/inNFTland).

[https://twitter.com/inNFTland/status/1550227700505264129](https://twitter.com/inNFTland/status/1550227700505264129)

I was also fortunate to bump into Ricky O’Donnell, Weird Whales holder and a huge supporter of young talent in this space.

[https://twitter.com/RickyODonnell79/status/1550222666686238720](https://twitter.com/RickyODonnell79/status/1550222666686238720)

Great venue, great weather and the perfect opportunity to make new friends.

[https://twitter.com/TianaImafidon/status/1550201338159587330](https://twitter.com/TianaImafidon/status/1550201338159587330)

On Thursday evening we headed-off into town where we were hosted by the [Tech Circus](https://techcircus.io/) team for The Global NFT Summit Speakers Dinner.

[https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1550374922597318657](https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1550374922597318657)

On Friday, we attended The Global NFT Summit. I spoke about web3 data and analytics and provided a demo using [NFTGo](https://nftgo.io/).

https://twitter.com/Alex91667079/status/1550957442787381248

Bumped into Lady of Crypto and talked about my journey.

[https://twitter.com/LadyofCrypto1/status/1550474946484355072](https://twitter.com/LadyofCrypto1/status/1550474946484355072)

I also met [Sebastian Borget](https://twitter.com/borgetsebastien) from [Sandbox](https://www.sandbox.game/en/) and [Robby Yung](https://twitter.com/viewfromhk) from [Animoca Brands](https://www.animocabrands.com/). Two huge personalities in the metaverse space.

[https://twitter.com/viewfromhk/status/1550474503691665408](https://twitter.com/viewfromhk/status/1550474503691665408)

I am looking forward to hearing more from Robby when we arrange to host him on the Work in Fintech [podcast](https://workinfintech.com/podcast), as expected, he has an immense amount of knowledge around gaming, web3 and metaverse.

[https://twitter.com/RenoviNFT/status/1550495456056287232](https://twitter.com/RenoviNFT/status/1550495456056287232)

At the after talks networking events I met Oliver Phelps from Harry Potter [fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_and_Oliver_Phelps). We had an interesting talk about my story and he was genuinely interested in the NFT space.

As we are continuously told, the crossover between film and NFTs will be a revolutionary moment for the industry.

[https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1550954589972844544](https://twitter.com/ObiWanBenoni/status/1550954589972844544)

title: Transitioning into the unknown, rolling -into- the abyss.
body:
**In an accelerated attempt, a group of people are working to decrypt the mysterious leviathan called Film3: This is the pitch** 

The story of the Blockchain has already been told hundreds of times, going from the first anonymous writings of who (who?) has known to be Satoshi Nakamoto to the endless stories of DeFi summer 2020, the exponential growth of NFTs and the renewal of multiple industries such as finance, video games, art and community building.  And on the other hand, from the first minstrels and troubadours telling stories of heroes and dynasties to the Lumiere brothers projecting their first films, we humans are thirsty for stories that make our imagination run wild and challenge the reality in which we live.

It is in this infinite scenario of uncertainty that I am writing to you. To begin with, let me introduce myself. My name is Portuno, and I am greeting you from the apathetic Bear Market. Rug pulls, scams and billion-dollar companies going bankrupt do nothing but occupy the front page of the crypto spaces, and a mere mention in the news of a world that is ravaged by wars, pestilence, recession and a climate that seems to be punishing us for the unholy sins of generations that still control the world.  But still, with the horsemen of the apocalypse looming at the sound of end of the world bells, I am a hopeful person for the future. A little bit because of that innocent innocence that I have been able to protect, but mainly because I have had the opportunity to meet hard-working people with an enviable ethic of doing things right. The good things. And of those people I want to talk to you now.

**If you allow me to start the Pitch, have you ever heard of Film3?** 

Blessed by the grace of the muses, the artist is the one who manages to capture an ephemeral expression of the soul, whose only limits are the known barriers of technology, and the unknown frontiers of the imagination.

As for the second, I do not have much more to do than to wish you, from the bottom of my heart, the best of luck. But about the first one, I promise to expand -in an unnecessarily long way- on how new technologies are allowing to explore areas of creativity never seen before, with tools of which past generations could feel nothing but envy towards those who wish to embark on this today. Cinema is going to change.

Technology will always be met with popular resistance of fear, it is inevitable. For those brave and courageous people who dare to try something new, know that animation has not replaced shadow play, just as there will be no image generated by Artificial Intelligence capable of eliminating the [Cave of Hands](https://www.timetravelturtle.com/cave-hands-patagonia-argentina/). Artificial Intelligence, Augmented/Virtual Reality and Blockchain are the triad of tools that artists have within our reach to know, learn and use. But as Jack the Reaper once said, “let's go by parts”.

 

**I)              Artificial Intelligence:**

Luckily I don't have a Skynet sending robots with Austrian accents from the future to kill me (or so I want to believe), and I didn't get to feel the affection that Joaquin Phoenix expressed for a code. But if there is one thing I am certain of, it is that the idea of creating something intelligent, capable of thinking for itself, has been somewhere hidden in our imagination for millennia, and what we could think of, we have built. We still do not have a Frankenstein walking among us, a Golem fulfilling our commands, and the few gargoyles I have seen in churches have remained immobile, denying me the dream of seeing them fly, but the ideas of great authors of the past are much closer than we think.

IA is the oldest of the technologies we will look at in this article, with its first steps in the 1950s, with heavy investment by the U.S. Army for the purpose of creating... who knows what they wanted to accomplish. But the project died in less than a decade, with the idea that a program incapable of beating people in a game of Checkers would be of little use in the impending nuclear war against the Soviets. Fortunately, the atomic bombs never exploded, allowing us to be alive to see the rebirth of this technology. Now with exponentially more powerful computers than in its time, with a worldwide connection network, and with a marketing rebranding to Machine Learning.

Back to our business. Art.  Artificial intelligence methods have opened up an endless number of new artistic experiences, most of which have not yet been thought of by any artist. From my limited memory, I remember how at the end of the last decade there was a proliferation of scripts written by code, where users provided specific content to it and it managed to recreate hilarious and bizarre scenes. This past year, 2022 for those who read me in the future, projects capable of creating self-generated images with the input of a description are seeing the light of day. A scene, an animal, something new. It can be a photo, a drawing, a painting or whatever we can think of, the biggest challenge is learning to communicate with the computer so that it can capture, in a matter of seconds, the idea we have in our minds.

The growth of all these things has been tremendous. Not only is the output of the scripts and images going to be better, but the tools are not going to be limited to just that. Animations, video games, interactive stories, entire movies would be created with just a few commands from the new artist. The sky is no longer the limit, and I don't know how many are looking at the moon for anything other than its infinite beauty. We are aiming for the stars.

 

**II)           Augmented/Virtual Reality**

More than one billion. 1.000.000.000. That's how many times Pokemon Go was downloaded. With a frenzy of new users in its first quarter and saturating servers in the first few weeks, Pokemon Go managed to break record after record in terms of downloads, users, time spent and revenue. The popularity of the game helped a lot, but it was the great novelty in augmented reality that positioned it on the podium. In mid-2016, it was impossible to walk down the street without coming across someone in a hurry, looking at their cell phone, thinking about capturing some virtual specimen or group of friends trying to win a gym. And I won't deny it, possibly the year I walked the most, and I still talk to my friends from team Instict!

Beyond the technical errors it had, and the delay in providing new content, the game was fun. Its fame faded and today its players are no longer a habitué of the cities, but the game is still there, at the top of the download rankings. But even more importantly, it paved the way for new games and projects to incorporate the idea that we, the users, can explore an alternative reality to the world we inhabit from our cell phones. Dinosaurs, monsters, zombies and magic now exist among us, in a sort of parallel reality unable to affect us unless we want it to. 

Virtual reality is a step further. We are no longer transiting in our reality modified by the presence of computational beings, but it is the absolute immersion of our being in a new dimension. All our senses (or at least hearing and sight for now), are no longer attentive to the reality of the physical body but are in a new world. Although the term dates back to the late 1980s, it was in the early 2010s that the first commercially available device capable of transporting us to this new place was released. A new medium where the artist can create content with a level of immersion never seen before.

 

**III)        Blockchain.**

The most famous and misunderstood of the public ledger. Born in the hidden forums, under the idea of the most undoxed entity of our time, we have the Blockchain. Indispensable tool for the creation of virtual and decentralized money, it has managed to become the most important canvas of humanity since the renaissance. Falling into this Rabbit Hole, it is almost impossible not to think about the possibility of decentralizing absolutely all human social functionality. There is no organization that cannot become a DAO, and every problem is easily solvable with a Smart Contract. Then comes reality, when the limitations of technology and human creativity appear for the first time and our futuristic dreams of reality become science fiction.

Web3 is a controversial term to date, let alone DAOs or NFTs. And it was at this moment of discontent with the countless acronyms that Film3 was born. More related to the Blockchain art niche than the others, but not limited to any possible solution to the problems plaguing modern filmmakers.

The task of pinpointing a beginning for this whole new industry is nearly impossible. As the months went by, I kept discovering new projects that, autonomously and independently, began to work on ideas to incorporate these new Web3 tools to solve the problems that had become deeply ingrained in the creative process of filmmaking. Naming them will be an activity for another time. But if there is a place to keep in mind, a place to go whenever you are looking for information, contacts or a good chat, like an inn of yesteryear, it is NFT Film Squad.  It is still hard for me to define it, it is not a project with a product in sight, there is no funding or treasury, but all those characteristics that would make it an unfeasible project in the crypto space, is what ultimately makes NFT Film Squad the ideal place for everyone. Experienced filmmakers, animators, writers, investors. People with projects in creation or Blockchain experts. Lawyers and cinephiles, everyone has a place to learn and participate.

 

**Problems.**

The product, ultimately, is the community. And the only investment available is your time. If there's one thing that really interests you about the business, it's the right place. Personally, I am a lawyer from Latin America who had little experience and knowledge of the entire film industry. I love movies, yes, but it was in these months of exploring and talking to countless artists, producers and related people that I discovered the problems they had. I knew that filmmaking was an expensive and difficult enterprise, but I found a reality that made it unnecessarily difficult for those who work outside of the big, well-known companies. At the moment, unlike the vast majority of crypto spaces, Film3 is populated mostly by artists. Programmers, financiers, lawyers and people from any other field are more than welcome to contribute their own knowledge and perspectives.

After countless hours of listening to these artists, there is a pentagram of problems that were repeated with alarming frequency when it came to turning an idea into a film. And these can be summarized as: Financing, Distributing, Networking, Royalties and Intellectual Property.

 

**I)              Financing**

The most repeated of all. There are three main methods for getting enough funding to move a script into pre-production. The first is self-financing, which occurs when the team in charge of the film manages, by its own means, to bear the operating costs of making a film. With this there is not much more to add, my congratulations to those who achieve it.

The second usually works with Kickstarter tools, where the artist makes a presentation sufficient to expose it to the public and request donations to obtain the resources.

The third is through producers. There are usually few with enough money to finance a film, and it is this advantage that positions them in a position of extreme advantage against the artist. Contracts with abusive clauses, decision-making power on multiple issues such as the hiring of actors, filming locations or even being able to modify the script.

 

**II)           Distributing**

The distribution of the work is the big problem that artists face once they have the finished product. The first comes from long before filming began, and it is the question of "where do we want our film to be seen?". It is very different to think and make a film with the idea of ​​seeing it on the big screen, with something ideal to be seen from the comfort of our home.

Either way, for those whose film is not completely in the hands of the aforementioned large companies, the favorite place to exhibit the creation is at film festivals. Luxurious, glorious and full of opportunities to receive critics that many times we are not prepared to listen to, they will probably be the first people with no subjective interest to see the finished work. But it is not easy to get the opportunity to shoot our film in those places.

On the other hand, it is very common to go to the big streaming platforms, which for some reason beyond my limited knowledge of economics, are more and more, and yet the idea that their monopoly is getting bigger and bigger is resented. We could talk about oligopoly instead, but this is not an evaluation.

 

**III)        Networking**

It costs a lot to do something. But sometimes the hardest thing is finding the right people to work with as a team. if you want to go fast, go alone; if you want to go far, go together.

When it comes to films, the geographic locations to go to have always been very limited. Los Angeles was always the iconic place to go if you wanted to have a career in the seventh art, and in a less US-centric view, Bollywood in India, Hallyowood in South Korea or Nollywood in Nigeria. However, there are two things in common in all of them. First, they are not locations per se but the term refers to the film industry as a whole. And secondly, more attuned to the idea I want to get across, it is a Hollywood-inspired name. Which is a place. And it's in Los Angeles.

In short, unless you're targeting a local market, Los Angeles has always been the dream destination for filmmakers with aspirations of growth and fame.  And the festivals? Cannes Films Festival (France), Sundance Film Festival (USA), Venice Film Festival (Italy), Toronto International Film Festival (Canada), all events that take place in the first world. And access to them is the first of the problems, the costs of travel, per diem, lodging and even food in some cases exceeds the budget that an artist without resources can access.

The Internet gave us the tools to eliminate those borders, and Film3 is giving us the communities so that we can communicate regardless of geographical distances. Within our reach are people working from all over the world, from whom we can not only learn and create links, but also collaborate with each other. There is nothing stopping a writer from Uruguay from writing scripts for a director from Portugal to direct his film. Animators from Nigeria and voice actors from Australia can work together on the same project.

 

IV)          **Intellectual Property**

We are entering the most complicated of problems. The legal ones. And intellectual property is precisely the film industry's most valuable asset. And there are several issues to analyze. The first one, probably the most important when it comes to the question of what it will be, is the location. The intellectual property laws in force will be the jurisdiction of the country, and each country has its own laws, with some countries (e.g., the United States) that, due to their federal nature, have different laws among their own states. A film from Argentina is not the same as a film from Pakistan, and a film from Chicago is not the same as a film from Texas.

And we must also take into consideration that it is a broad term, since copyright, trademark, privacy rights and publicity rights fall under the umbrella of "intellectual property".

In cases where the artist is hired by a production company to make a film (Work-Made-for-Hire), the issue is not a problem. The owner of the film is the company and there is no dispute.

But when one is the creator. When you write the scripts, develop the story, invent the characters and put your effort into creating something, the ownership of it is a token of all the effort. A small token of pride at the conclusion of an adventure, the ultimate prize of a quest. And many times it must be guarded with suspicion, because there are ill-intentioned people everywhere. An abusive contract or an unscrupulous listener can take away the filmmaker's power over his work without it even realizing it.

**V)            Royalties**

Royalties are a separate issue. Within intellectual property, it is perhaps the most controversial area.  They are the right that a person has to charge on the income generated by the work.

DVD sales, movie ticket sales, streaming platform sales. There are many ways of accounting for them and more and more, but the bottom line is the same. Who gets these royalties?

As if it were a company paying dividends to its shareholders according to the amount of equity they have, there are many cases of artists who end up relegating the possibility of continuing to earn money with their works.

 

**A final word**

Based on all these problems, solutions have been created. Some of them are practical and others very fanciful. Some are already in operation and others are still an idea. But the important thing is that they are there. And for those unsolved problems, we need you.

NFT Film Squad is an open community where you will be able to join, learn and collaborate from different approaches. On Twitter there are weekly spaces with an admirable frequency and in different languages (Spanish and English for now), where all these issues have already been addressed countless times by any project that appears. Directors, producers, lawyers, writers or animators are just some of the professions that have had the opportunity to express their doubts and concerns in this new space, of which we still do not know much, but we are willing to go into the depths of the unknown to have the chance to learn.

We are all welcome.

title: What the hell are we talking about when it comes to web3 privacy?
body:
### Disclaimer

The writing of this article is based on some recent observations, discussions and reflections on this issue by the author and the team. This article does not focus on technical solutions, but proposes certain problems and directions from the perspective of first principles. There are some specific terminologies that are not specially articulated, and interested readers can Google it by themselves.

## The Beginning of Web2 Privacy Protection

In recent years, privacy protection has been a topic of great concern in the Internet field. With the popularization of big data and the advancement of recommendation algorithms, while feeling the convenience of "smart" services, more and more users are beginning to discover the disadvantages of not owning their own data. Endless targeted advertisements, information cocoon rooms, etc. are even the most harmless consequences. More often, our information faces various threats such as abuse, leakage and resale.

As a result, various regulations such as GDPR and CCPA came into being, and technologies such as federated learning and privacy computing have also become hot topics and research directions. However, despite all this heat, in the web2 Internet most of the time, the user's feeling is still, "they know too much".

## Web3 - Privacy by Default?

When the concept of web3 came out, almost immediately everyone thought, "This is it". Everyone hides behind a wallet address and can do almost everything without any real identity. The concept of web3 is based on regaining ownership, which includes ownership of the entire computing network, ownership of the economic system, and ownership of your own identity and data. It seems all natural that privacy concerns are solved in a web3 world.

But is this the case? We can try to observe some of the web3 areas that most users are most involved in.

In the field of NFT, an increasing number of projects need to resist Sybil attacks. Some leading projects such as Otherdeed requires KYC for their users, and even projects that don’t require KYC such as Moonbird have also banned suspected linked accounts. Bot check, uniqueness check, ID check, selfie upload, users will be asked to share some information about themselves from the simplest task completion to the most sensitive ID cards and selfies, more or less. NFT projects, on the other hand, have to strike a difficult balance between protecting themselves and retaining users.

In the Defi field, almost all lending is currently based on mortgages, and due to the strong volatility of encrypted assets, the lending and mortgage rates are usually not ideal. Projects trying to build on-chain reputation have only recently begun to emerge, but it is difficult to determine whether on-chain data is currently sufficient to support unsecured/low-collateralized lending.

Decentralized exchanges are basically avoiding the need to collect user information in the current environment where regulators are basically still absent. But fast forward to a few years later, local governments will inevitably have certain KYC requirements on those exchanges. These requirements may not be as intense as for Cefi, but some major legal risks, such as anti-money laundering, sanctions lists, tax withholding, etc., will be put on the agenda in the foreseeable future.

`It is not difficult to find that in the current Web3 world, the issue of privacy is not really solved. On the contrary, in most scenes, we are just avoiding the concept of "I" as much as possible. If something does not inherently need to know anything about the participants, then there is no need to protect anyone's privacy.`

## How to Define Privacy for Web3

So how do we define privacy and privacy protection when we participate in richer web3 activities that do require more information about participants? Is not telling the project my real-world identity information a necessary and sufficient condition for privacy protection?

For example. Project A needs to know which country you are a citizen of. Although this information is about your real-world identity, there are so many people who have the same information and it is not a piece of information that can be used to identify and relate to specifically you (PII) , and therefore it’s less sensitive. At the same time, another project B wants to know who you are following on SocialFi. This information is completely on chain, but what if the wallet address you use in the SocialFi is your commonly used address, and the ENS of this address is also presented in your Twitter account which you spent years building as a tech blogger and entrepreneur mentor. Do you still want to reveal to the public all that you followed on that SocialFi are good-looking KOLs? Or in some other cases do you even want people to know that you're a user of an unpopular SocialFi?

In the past in web2 world, people usually only paid more attention to the privacy of physical identities, because we were worried about cyber violence, regulation, threats, etc. against our physical identities, and at the same time, we thought that accounts on the Internet were just things that can be changed at will and discarded at any time. But as the information surrounding wallet addresses in the web3 world becomes more and more abundant, `my wallet address also forms an "I" in this virtual world. This "I" has nothing to do with me in the real world, its reputation requires time and effort to establish, so it cannot be discarded and replaced casually, but at the same time "I" also have some information that I only want to use in certain situations, but not kept public.`

In today's web3 world, however, there is little privacy for these "I"s. What all addresses own, whether it is ERC20 tokens, NFT, or Soulbound Tokens, can be viewed by everyone. The state, call history and call parameters in all smart contracts are all public information. "I" either choose to encrypt and store all my important information, making them completely untrustworthy or unavailable, or choose to make them completely public. As we mentioned above, this situation is not limited to the user's physical identity information, in fact all valuable on-chain information is in the same state.

[The W3C definition of privacy](https://www.w3.org/TR/vc-data-model/#spectrum-of-privacy) gives a spectrum based on relevance. Some of the information about "I" is desensitized, like I'm older than 21. This is a piece of content about me, but it is almost impossible to relate to me based on this information. Some information is weakly related, such as name, birthday, zip code, etc. In most cases, there are many people with the same information, so it is not easy to relate to me through this, although not entirely impossible either. On the other end of the spectrum are all kinds of unique identifiers, including my government ID, email, or the address of my usual wallet. When any personal information along with an unique identifier are together in the possession of someone, they have that unique "I’s" privacy information.

`Regardless of web2 or web3, the focus of privacy protection is not to prevent any information from being shared, but to not reveal the relationship between various "Is" and the information in the process of information sharing.`

## Sharing of Private Data

In practice, in order not to expose too much information about "I", when we have to share, we may do something like this:

* Descope: Only share the information that the other party must need. The finer the granularity, the better. If I can share a first name only, don’t share the last name.
* Desensitize: Share desensitized information. returns 1370\*\*\*\*\*93 instead of the full mobile number.
* Computation: Advance the calculation process before data sharing. For example, the other party needs to know if I am allowed to drink, if I am in the United States, I need to be older than 21, and if I am in China, I need to be older than 18. I can only share yes or no with the requester without sharing any information about where I am and how old I am.

These methods reduce the risk of information exposure to a certain extent, but they are not enough. Here we need to mention two more concepts, identifier-based correlation and signature-based correlation.

For example, I used wallet W to participate in a project A that I did not trust very much. I provided them with my country of residence - US upon request, and thought it was no problem to provide this kind of insensitive information. The next day I used W to participate in another hot project B, and provided them with my driver's license. Some readers may have realized that even though here we reduced the information provided to the projects each time through descope, when they collaborate and put together the information they have, they get more information about me due to the common wallet address W, while I have no desire to share more information with them.

In these cases, the data held by any party is still valuable outside of their own usage scenarios, so my data security now can only rely on the good will of each project and the professionalism of their security teams. This is identifier-based correlation. The signature based correlation is a similar concept. Since this article does not focus on the topic of verification, interested readers can go to [W3C](https://www.w3.org/TR/vc-data-model/#signature-based-correlation) to learn more.

## Privacy vs Convenience

In an environment where information sharing exists, I believe that the definition of good privacy protection should be: `Anyone's knowledge about any "I" can only come from "I"'s own sharing and interactions records collected under the "I"’s content.`

In practice, this means that we must cut off the correlation between each sharing of information as much as possible. More specifically, the information you share with others cannot contain any identifiers that can uniquely identify you.

Broadly speaking, names, birthdays, zip codes, etc. are also at risk of being identified, while government IDs, phone numbers, email addresses, Twitter usernames, etc. must not be shared, which is not difficult to do. The hard part is the wallet address. `In order to eliminate identifier-based correlations, we need to use different wallets each time we participate in a project who needs to collect our information.`Only in this way, the data we share with any project, even if it is resold by the project or stolen by hackers, cannot be used to enrich the database of other projects (because we use other addresses there), so there is little value to steal and resell them.

But doing so obviously creates many other problems. Trouble is one of them. We need to manage a lot of wallets and switch to the correct wallet for every project. In daily use, some means are also needed to hide the transactions and associations between wallets.

The bigger problem is that such operations cut off many of the conveniences that web3's open environment brings. The wallet you used in the past represented your proud identity in the web3 world. What kind of early projects have you participated in, what NFTs or Tokens have you invested in, which DAOs have you contributed to and where have you accumulated some reputation? These definitions for you are publicly available for anyone to see, and they can also use these definitions and history about you to give you benefits such as airdrops, whitelists, better mortgage lending rates, and more. If you hide these associations and records now, you will undoubtedly lose these conveniences and benefits.

The same paradox of privacy vs convenience also exists in web2. We often have to admit that the recommendation systems based on our data really understand our preferences and needs. As long as we trust Google to securely save my information,  Sign in with Google or managed passwords are really life savers. It's just that we can't ignore the elephant in the room, which is that our data is completely controlled by these big companies, with which they can even control our minds and actions. Faced with such a tradeoff, for a long time, we could only choose a comfortable point in the spectrum of convenience or privacy.

## The Future?

Can web3 solve this problem? Can we no longer choose between privacy and convenience, but have both? I believe it is possible, but not through the direct use of web3. It requires us to build a set of standards that support privacy protection and an ecosystem that participates in the standards. The basic construction of web3 already supports allowing users to own their data and giving them the right to freely choose how to use it. What we need to do now is to build a convenient and secure framework for them to use their data for all the benefits, while not revealing the data itself. This is exactly what the author and team are working hard to build, and stay tuned for more progress in our subsequent releases.

If you are interested, please contact us at contact@jomo.network
